step_by_step.explanation: International trade is the exchange of goods and services between countries.

problems.final_answer: International trade: exchange of goods and services across countries.

step_by_step.explanation: A country has an absolute advantage if it can produce a good using fewer resources than another country.

problems.final_answer: Absolute advantage: produce a good using fewer resources than another country.

step_by_step.explanation: A country has a comparative advantage if it can produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another country.

problems.final_answer: Comparative advantage: produce a good at lower opportunity cost than another country.

step_by_step.explanation: By specializing in goods with comparative advantage and trading, countries can consume beyond their production possibilities.

problems.final_answer: Gains from trade: specialization + trade → consumption beyond production possibilities.

step_by_step.explanation: Balance of payments records all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world, including trade, services, and capital flows.

problems.final_answer: Balance of payments: record of all international transactions.

problems.problem: Differentiate trade surplus and trade deficit.
problems.final_answer: Trade surplus: exports > imports; Trade deficit: imports > exports.

step_by_step.explanation: Protectionism involves government policies that restrict imports to protect domestic industries, e.g., tariffs, quotas, and subsidies.

problems.final_answer: Protectionism: policies restricting imports to protect domestic industries.

step_by_step.explanation: A tariff is a tax on imported goods, raising their price to protect domestic producers and generate government revenue.

problems.final_answer: Tariffs: taxes on imports → protect domestic industries and raise revenue.

step_by_step.explanation: A quota is a limit on the quantity of imports allowed, restricting foreign competition and protecting domestic industries.

problems.final_answer: Quotas: limits on imports → restrict foreign competition, protect domestic industries.

problems.problem: Explain the benefits of free trade agreements.

step_by_step.explanation: Free trade agreements reduce or eliminate trade barriers among member countries, increasing efficiency, specialization, and economic growth.

problems.final_answer: Free trade agreements: lower trade barriers → efficiency, specialization, economic growth.
